title: tasting_charts
text:
Coffee connoisseurs or some may say ‘coffee snobs’? Who are they and what are the trends we see today? Let’s find out! Admittedly, this is a greatly biased sample of coffee enthusiasts most likely those leaning who watch YouTube.







Caption One

Caption two

title: James Hoffman: Analysis of ‘The Great American Coffee Taste Test Live Stream’
text:
wordcloud c - adjust size - or render it smaller? change h2 color gt font size paragraph line spacing
1:56 compare gender to whole population lots more polarizing, esp in females 1543 national coffee pour over and light roast preference subcap instead of caption? italic for word cloud title Roast levels, processing method, region, elevation, variety, all play a role in the coffee tasting experience.
“what_is_your_favorite_coffee_drink” “before_today_s_tasting_which_of_the_following_best_described_what_kind_of_coffee_you_like” “What.roast.level.of.coffee.do.you.prefer.” Price of these drinks?? pour-over - more likely to drink black? perceived acid and roast level - relationship?
correlation bwn actual pref vs taste pref. roast level can be ambiguous
preference by expertise level
https://colorbrewer2.org/#type=qualitative&scheme=Set2&n=3 https://www.infoworld.com/video/108579/r-colors-and-palettes-tips-and-tools q
https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/colorspace/  ————————————————————————
The “Great America Taste Test” is what coffee expert and British YouTuber James Hoffman called the live stream coffee tasting event held in October 2023. 5,000 Americans participated in this simultaneous coffee sipping event where each participant tasted the same four coffees. They were then asked to fill out a survey with around 10 questions ranging from coffee drinking habits to describing the coffee flavors of the four coffees.
I decided to analyze the results! I performed a text analysis of the coffees tasted and looked at the demographics and coffee habits of the participants. Here I looked at standard bitterness and acidity in each coffee then I went deeper to find if there were commonalities in coffee flavor notes via a text analysis. Of the 5,000 participants, a survey was completed by 4,042 of them.

title: James Hoffman: Analysis of ‘The Great American Coffee Taste Test Live Stream’
text:
Demographics
https://datareportal.com/essential-youtube-stats https://www.statista.com/statistics/810461/us-youtube-reach-gender/
Nearly 3 out of 4 (74%) participants were between ages 25 and 44 years while participants were overwhelming male at 62%. While James Hoffman is popular coffee expert on YouTube, overall YouTube demographics leans female (51%) and worldwide only 37% are between the ages of 25-44. This suggests Jame’s audience tend to be young and male.
Interestingly, we see a trend in drinking more cups of coffee per day as one ages. Who said college students drink lots of coffee, maybe we should say it’s the retirees who drink far more?




Participants by Gender

title: James Hoffman: Analysis of ‘The Great American Coffee Taste Test Live Stream’
text:
Spending Habits
Participants were asked to rate one’s own coffee expertise on a scale of 1 - 10. As one would expect, as one becomes more expert, one spends more money. That was very true for me, wanting to get the is a black hole. Those who rate themself as a 1 or 2 spend less than $20 a month. This suggests this group probably doesn’t drink a lot of specialty coffee since a bag costs $10-20 a bag.
We find similar patterns when asked how much a participant spent on coffee equipment over the past five years. While James says having a good coffee grinder makes for a better coffee, a decent one does cost for than $100. Again, this suggests folks with ‘1-2’ coffee expertise most likely do not own one.




Money Spent Each Month on Coffee









Money Spent Past 5 Years on Coffee Equipment

title: James Hoffman: Analysis of ‘The Great American Coffee Taste Test Live Stream’
text:
Coffee Cupping

What is Coffee Cupping?
Most of us have probably seen tasting notes when purchasing coffee (i.e. grapefruit, chocolate) but are these actually descriptive? Would someone describe similar notes of the same coffee? Is there a relationship between tasting notes and roast levels? To find this out, I looked at how participants ranked the level of bitterness and acidity of each coffee. Then they were asked to describe their tasting notes so I will explore this via a text analysis.
(pictures)(flavor wheel)


Bitterness and Acidity








Figure 9: Coffee Bitterness Scores













Figure 10: Coffee Acidity Scores











Table 2: Bitterness Statistics of Each Coffee

statistic
p.value




2.5623

9.7466
0.0000


6.9392
0.0000










To start, participants were asked to rate the level of bitterness and acidity of each coffee from a scale of 1 -5. Average bitterness among the four coffees show that Coffee A and Coffee D were similar while Coffee B and Coffee C were also similar. But are these averages between these two pair of coffee statistically significant. To find this out, I performed a one-sided t-test. show that the average may be different (p = xx).
Again, for acidity, we have similar patterns.


Flavor Notes
Cool we found a difference in bitterness and acidity in the coffees! So What does the coffee remind you of? was a repeated question James asked to describe the flavor notes. Comparing coffees side-by-side allows one to discover the nuances of each coffee. One may start with a general words such as ‘nutty.’ Below is a flavor wheel, a tool to help identify words for one’s taste buds.
(wheel) This cupping live stream demonstrates there’s actually some commonalities between tasting by the cupping participants.
Participants were asked to describe the coffee flavors in an open text field. I did a text analysis by identifying and counting key flavor words, such as ‘bright’ or ‘grapefruit.’ I took the top 25 most frequent words and made a word cloud. The larger the word, the frequent the word was mentioned (note-the count is in the hover text).
Coffee A conjures up images of something light and fruity. While Coffee B and Coffee C using ‘chocolate’ and ‘nutty’ as common descriptors and a few even described it as burnt. Coffee C has more of a spread in word counts.
Coffee D, however, paints a different image. ‘Fermented’ and ‘funky’ made it to the top - given this was a natural processed coffee this is not surprising!



Coffee A: Fruity: 616 Respondents






Coffee B: Chocolate: 600 Respondents








Coffee C: Chocolate: 332 Respondents






Coffee D: Fruity: 1,085 Respondents





Okay - so let’s see how these tasting notes match up on the flavor wheel. ‘Acid’, ‘Bitter’, ‘Sweet’, ‘Fruity’, and ‘Chocolate’ are generic words used to describe all 4 coffees. However, they were used at different frequencies as demonstrated in the word clouds. Looking at the yellow sectors, we do see a pattern for Coffee A and Coffee D compared to Coffee B and Coffee C.








Figure 11: Overlapping Taste Notes

title: James Hoffman: Analysis of ‘The Great American Coffee Taste Test Live Stream’
text:
The Four Coffees
Participants tasted four different coffees with different roasts ranging from light to dark. To ensure every participant tasted nearly the exact same coffee profile, coffee pods were shipped flash frozen liquid of concentrated coffee, needing only to add hot water.













Coffee
Roast.Level
Origin






Coffee A

Light
Single - Kenya




Coffee B

Medium
Multiple - Blend




Coffee C

Dark
Multiple - Blend




Coffee D

Light
Single - Columbia







The chart above shows the 4 coffees: 3 coffees with roast levels of light, medium, and dark along and then a 4th Coffee, Coffee D, a light roast coffee but with a unique processing method - anaerobic natural process - this tends to give the coffee a heavy fruity and fermented taste.  Based on these four coffees, how do you think the tastes will compare? Which would you think are more bitter or more acidic?

title: James Hoffman: Analysis of ‘The Great American Coffee Taste Test Live Stream’
text:
Coffee Spending Habits
As one would expect, as one becomes more expert, one spends more money. That was very true for me as I fell into black hole of striving the perfect my coffee game. Nearly half (48%) of those who rate themself as a 1 or 2 spend less than $20 a month. This suggests this group probably doesn’t drink a lot of specialty coffee since a bag costs $10-20 a bag.
We find similar patterns when asked how much a participant spent on coffee equipment over the past five years. While James says having a good coffee grinder makes for a better coffee, a decent one does cost for than $100. Again, this suggests folks with ‘1-2’ coffee expertise most likely do not own one.




Money Spent Each Month on Coffee









Money Spent Past 5 Years on Coffee Equipment

title: Welcome To My Blog

https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/colorspace/ 
The “Great America Taste Test” is what coffee expert and British YouTuber James Hoffman called the live stream coffee tasting event held in October 2023. 5,000 Americans participated in this simultaneous coffee sipping event where each participant tasted the same four coffees.
Participants were filled out a survey - so let’s analyze the results! I performed a text analysis of the coffees tasted and looked at the demographics and coffee habits of the participants.

title: James Hoffman: Analysis of ‘The Great American Coffee Taste Test Live Stream’
text:
Demographics / Traits
Nearly 3 out of 4 (74%) participants were between ages 25 and 44 years compared to the worldwide YouTube audience where only 37% are between the ages of 25-44 1. Participants are also overwhelming male representing 62% of participants verse U.S. YouTube demographics where 49% are male 2.
This suggests James’ audience tend to be younger and male, minimizing the YouTube bias.. Perhaps because specialty coffee started to arise in the early 2000s.


I also looked at the breakdown of daily coffee drinking by age. Interestingly, we see a trend in drinking more cups of coffee per day as one ages. Who said college students drink lots of coffee, maybe we should say it’s the retirees who drink far more?

title: Post With Code
text:
This is a post with executable code.

1 + 1

[1] 2

title: James Hoffman: Analysis of ‘The Great American Coffee Taste Test Live Stream’
text:
What Were The Four Coffees?
Participants tasted four different coffees with different roasts ranging from light to dark. To ensure every participant tasted nearly the exact same coffee profile, coffee pods were shipped flash frozen liquid of concentrated coffee, needing only to add hot water.













Coffee
Roast Level
Origin






Coffee A

Light
Single - Kenya




Coffee B

Medium
Multiple - Blend




Coffee C

Dark
Multiple - Blend




Coffee D

Light
Single - Columbia







The chart above shows the 4 coffees: 3 coffees with roast levels of light, medium, and dark along and then a 4th Coffee, Coffee D, a light roast coffee but with a unique processing method - anaerobic natural process - this tends to give the coffee a heavy fruity and fermented taste.
Based on these four coffees, how do you think the tastes will compare? Which would you think are more bitter or more acidic?

title: James Hoffman: Analysis of ‘The Great American Coffee Taste Test Live Stream’
text:
Coffee Expertise
Participants were asked to rate one’s own coffee expertise on a scale of 1 - 10. Not surprisingly, we see participants lean towards the upper half with nearly half (45%) rating themselves as a 6 or 7. However, there is still a significant number on the lower end and very few at a 9 or 10, pulling the overall average down to 5.7. As to more easily compare these groups throughout my analysis, I binned one’s level of expertise into five groups. Now, the ‘5-6’ and ‘7-8’ expertise groups make up about the same proportion (36% each) while the ‘9-10’ expertise group make up only 3% of total participants.












Figure 2: Self-Rated Coffee Expertise











Figure 3: Binned Self-Rated Coffee Expertise Groups

title: James Hoffman: Analysis of ‘The Great American Coffee Taste Test Live Stream’
section: So What Were The Four Coffees?
text:
So What Were The Four Coffees?
The four different coffees were each of a different roast: light, medium, and dark. The fourth coffee, Coffee D, is a light roast coffee but with a unique processing method - anaerobic natural process - this tends to give the coffee a heavy fruity and fermented taste.
To ensure every participant tasted nearly the exact same coffee profile, coffee pods were shipped flash frozen liquid of concentrated coffee, needing only to add hot water.













Coffee
Roast Level
Origin






Coffee A

Light
Single - Kenya




Coffee B

Medium
Multiple - Blend




Coffee C

Dark
Multiple - Blend




Coffee D

Light
Single - Columbia







Based on these four coffees, how do you think the tastes will compare? Which would you think are more bitter or more acidic?

title: James Hoffman: Analysis of ‘The Great American Coffee Taste Test Live Stream’
text:
Coffee Habits

Coffee Drinking Habits


Let’s explore the coffee drinking habits by expertise group.









Figure 4: If Participants Drink Coffee Just Black by Expertise Group















Figure 5: Daily Coffee Drinks by Expertise Group













Figure 6: Favorite Coffee Drink of Participants







Spending Habits
As one would expect, as one becomes more experienced in a hobby, one spends more money. That was very true for me as I fell into black hole of striving to perfect my coffee game, wanting to buy the top gear given my budget.
For the folks with less expertise, nearly half (48%) of them spend less than $20 a month. Figure 5 showed that this group does drink less coffee. They also probably don’t drink a lot of specialty coffee since a bag costs $10-20 a bag nor drink coffee at specialty cafes.
We find similar a pattern when asked how much a participant spent on coffee equipment over the past five years. While James says having a good coffee grinder makes for a better coffee, a decent one does cost for than $100. Again, this suggests folks with ‘1-2’ coffee expertise most likely do not own one.
I wonder if this group has a coffee preference, one akin to Folger’s








Figure 7: Money Spent Each Month on Coffee by Coffee Expertise













Figure 8: Money Spent Over the Past 5 Years on Coffee Equipment by Coffee Expertise
